thread.section_title: Australian Business & World Finance News - Yahoo!7 Finance
thread.title: Aust shares open 1% lower

title: Aust shares open 1% lower
text:
Thu, Aug 20, 2015, 11:16 AM AEST - Australia Markets close in 4 hrs 44 mins Aust shares open 1% lower AAP â€“ 9 minutes ago Print 
The Australian share market is more than one per cent lower, weighed down by negativity over the US Federal Reserve minutes and an oversupply of oil in the US. 
The minutes of the Fed's July meeting showed there were doubts about the likelihood of an interest rate hike in September, with members wanting to see more evidence of sustained economic growth. 
IG market analyst Angus Nicholson said it was a poor performance across the board on the Aussie stock market. 
"The big news here is that Asian markets and here in Australia aren't responding well to the Fed, and the supply data that came out overnight that showed there was much more oil capacity in the United States has really hit oil stocks," he said. 
"The energy sector is leading the declines." 
Woodside Petroleum was down four per cent, at $31.57, Santos fell 4.8 per cent to $5.75 and Oil Search lost 4.6 per cent to $6.24. 
In the mining sector, BHP Billiton was down three per cent at $24.40, Rio Tinto was 2.5 per cent worse off at $49.40, and Fortescue Metals lost 1.75 per cent to $1.9275. 
AMP shares were down two cents to $6.26, despite increasing its dividend after a 33 per cent lift in first half profit. 
The other financial stocks were also retreating in line with the broader market. 
At 1033 AEST, Commonwealth Bank shares were down 84 cents at $77.43, Westpac had fallen 14 cents to $32.57, NAB had lost 27 cents to $32.31 and the ANZ fell 35.5 cents to $29.485. 
APN News & Media has suffered a 17 per cent blow to its share price, following a slide in first half profit. Shares in the trans-Tasman radio and newspaper owner were down 11 cents at 55 cents. 
Coles owner Wesfarmers got a boost after it lifted its underlying profit 8.3 per cent to $2.44 billion. Its shares were 46 cents higher, at $40.84. 
Bucking the trend was Qantas, with its shares up 1.5 cents to $3.775. 
It announced that its shareholders will receive a $505 million cash windfall following a $3.3 billion one-year profit turnaround. 
Vacuum cleaner retailer Godfreys lifted its full year profit by a third and is paying a special dividend to shareholders, which gave its shares a three per cent boost, to $3.13. 
KEY FACTS 
* At 1033 AEST, the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index was down 59.1 points, or one per cent, to 5,321.1 points. 
* The broader All Ordinaries index was down 55.5 points, or one per cent, to 5,324.3 points. 
* The September share price index futures contract was down 78 points at 5,275 with 13,607 contracts traded. 
* National turnover was 452 million securities worth $1.1 billion. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook
